You should have a general solution, which includes unknown constants. Your answer satisfies the differential equation, but does not have the correct number of unknown constants.

questiontext.text: Find the solution to \[ @q@ =0 \] subject to \[ y(0) = @y0@ \] and \[ y'(0) = @y1@ \] [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

falsefeedback.text: Your answer should satisfy the differential equation, but in fact when we substitute your expression into the differential equation we get \[@p@\] which is not zero, so you must have done something wrong.
Your answer should satisfy \[ y(0) = @y0@ \] but does not. When we substitute $t=0$ in your answer we get @b0@ instead.
Your answer should satisfy \[ y'(0) = @y1@ \] but does not. When we substitute $t=0$ into the derivative of your answer we get @b1@ instead.

questiontext.text:
Give an example of a function $f(x)$ with a stationary point at $x=@n@$ and which is continuous but not differentiable at $x=0$.

$f(x)=$[[input:ans1]]

[[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
One way to construct such a function is to start with a continuous curve (the first property) with a stationary point at $x=@n@$ and then to "bend" the curve at the point at which we need differentiability to fail.  This can be done using the absolute value function $|x|$.

We start with a quadratic with roots at $x=0$ and $x=2\times @n@$ which has a stationary point at the required $x=@n@$.  For example $x(x-@2*n@)$.  Now we can "bend" it with the absolute value function as follows:

\[ @abs(x)*(x-2*n)@\]

This is plotted below. @plot(abs(x)*(x-2*n),[x,-2,2*(n+1)])@

falsefeedback.text: Your answer does not have a stationary point at $x=@n@$ but should do.
Your answer fails to be continuous at $x=0$ but should be.
Your answer is differentiable at $x=0$ but should not be!  You were asked for a non-differentiable function at $x=0$.  Consider using $|x|$, which is entered as abs(x) somewhere in your answer.

questiontext.text:
Consider the real function

\[ f(x) :=\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} @f0@ & \mbox{for } x\leq @x0@, \\ p(x) & \mbox{for } @x0@ < x < @x1@, \\ @f1@ & \mbox{for } @x1@\leq x.\end{array} \right. \]

@plot(pg,[x,(x0-3),(x1+3)],[y,-3,3])@

Find the cubic polynomial $p(x)$ which makes $f(x)$ continuously differentiable. 

$p(x)=$[[input:ans1]]

[[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
First we need to find the information which $p(x)$ needs to satisfy.  This is

\[ p(@x0@)=@subst(x=x0,f0)@.\]

\[ p(@x1@)=@subst(x=x1,f1)@.\]

\[ p'(@x0@)=@subst(x=x0,diff(f0,x))@.\]

\[ p'(@x1@)=@subst(x=x1,diff(f1,x))@.\]

If we define $p(x)$ to be the cubic 

\[ p(x) = a_3 x^3 + a_2 x^2 + a_1 x + a_0,\]

We then set up the matrix equation

\[ @CS@ @CV@ = @CT@ \]

Solving this gives the coefficients, from which we get the polynomial.

@ta@.

feedbackvariables.text: anspt : if (x > x0 and x < x 1) then ans1 else 1000;

falsefeedback.text: Your answer does not satisfy $@p(x0)=subst(x=x0,f0)@$.
Your answer does not satisfy $@p(x1)=subst(x=x1,f1)@$.
Your answer does not satisfy $p'(@x0@)=@subst(x=x0,diff(f0,x))@$.
Your answer does not satisfy $p'(@x1@)=@subst(x=x1,diff(f1,x))@$.
Your answer is not a cubic!

Your answer is plotted below, although part of your graph might appear out of range of the plot!

@plot([pg,anspt],[x,(x0-3),(x1+3)],[y,-3,3])@

questiontext.text:
1. Give an example of an odd function by typing an expression which represents it. $f_1(x)=$ [[input:ans1]]. [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:odd]]

2. Give an example of an even function. $f_2(x)=$ [[input:ans2]]. [[validation:ans2]] [[bla,bla]]

3. Give an example of a function which is odd and even. $f_3(x)=$ [[input:ans3]]. [[validation:ans3]] [[bla,bla]]

4. Is the answer to 3. unique? [[input:ans4]] (Or are there many different possibilities.) [[validation:ans4]] [[feedback:unique]]

falsefeedback.text: Your answer is not an even function. Look, \[ f(x)-f(-x)=@sa@ \neq 0.\]
Your answer is not an odd function. Look, \[ f(x)+f(-x)=@sa@ \neq 0.\]
Your answer is not an odd function. Look, \[ f(x)+f(-x)=@sa1@ \neq 0.\]
Your answer is not an even function. Look, \[ f(x)-f(-x)=@sa2@ \neq 0.\]

questiontext.text:
In a railway journey of $90km$ an increase of $5$ kilometers per hour in the speed decreases the time taken by $15$ minutes.

Write a system of equations (one equation per line) to represent this situation using $v$ as the speed of the train and $t$ as the time.
[[input:asys]] [[validation:asys]] [[feedback:prt1]]

Eliminate $t$ from your equations, writing a single equation only in $v$ which represents this situation.
[[input:veqn]] [[validation:veqn]] [[feedback:prt2]]

What is the velocity? [[input:ansv]] [[validation:ansv]] [[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
Let $v$ be thespeed of the train, $d$ the distance travelled and $t$ time. If $t$ is the time (in hours) then $15$ minutes is $1/4$ hour.

We need to use the equation $d=v\times t$ twice.

For the original journey we have \[ 90 = v\times t.\] For the faster journey we have \[ 90 = (v+5)(t-1/4).\]

truefeedback.text: Please check your time units very carefully!

name.text: Find the line tangent to a random polynomial at a point.

questiontext.text:
Find the equation of the line tangent to $p(x):=@p@$ at the point $x=@pt@$.

1. Differentiate @p@ with respect to $x$. [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

2. Evaluate your derivative at $x=@pt@$. [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

3. Hence, find the equation of the tangent line to $p$ at $x=@pt@$. $y=$[[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. The derivative of @p@ with respect to $x$ is \[ @ta1@.\]

2. If we subsitiute $x=@pt@$ into $p'(x)$ we have $p'(@pt@)=@ta2@$.

3. The tangent line is given by the equation

\[ y = m(x-a)+c\]

where $m$ is the gradient of the line, $a$ is the point at which the tangent line is being contructed and $c:=p(a)$.  In our case we have $a=@pt@$, $m=@ta2@$ and $c=p(@pt@)=@c@$.  Combining these we have

\[ y=@ta2*(x-pt)+c@ = @ta3@.\]

falsefeedback.text: Your answer to this part is correct, however you have got part 1 wrong! Please try both parts again!

generalfeedback.text: We can either do this question by inspection (i.e. spot the answer) or in a more formal manner by using the substitution \[ u = (@v@-@a@).\] Then, since $\frac{d}{d@v@}u=1$ we have \[ \int @p@ d@v@ = \int u^@n@ du = \frac{u^@n+1@}{@n+1@}+c = @ta@+c.\]

questiontext.text:
A rectangle has length @sg@cm greater than its width. If it has an area of $@abs(ar)@cm^2$, find the dimensions of the rectangle.

1. Write down an equation which relates the side lengths to the area of the rectangle.
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:eq]]

2. Solve your equation. Enter your answer as a set of numbers.
[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:sol]]

3. Hence, find the length of the shorter side.
[[input:ans3]] cm [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:short]]

generalfeedback.text: If $x$cm is the width then $(x+@sg@)$ is the length. Now the area is $@abs(ar)@cm^2$ and so \[ @x*(x+sg)=-ar@.\] \[ @x^2+sg*x+ar@=0\] \[ @(x+rp)*(x+rn)=0@ \] So that $x=@-rp@$ or $x=@-rn@$. Since lengths are positive quantities $x>0$ and we discard the negative root. Hence the length of the shorter side is $x=@-rn@$cm.

truefeedback.text: You have correctly solved the equation you have entered in part 1. Please try both parts again!

generalfeedback.text:
To multiply matrices $A$ and $B$ we need to remember that the $(i,j)$th entry is the scalar product of the $i$th row of $A$ with the $j$th column of $B$.

\[ @A@.@B@ = @C@ = @D@.\]

truefeedback.text: Remember, you don't multiply matrices by multiplying the corresponding entries! A quite different process is needed.
Please multiply the matrices. It looks like you have added them instead!

generalfeedback.text:
It makes sense that the index laws should still apply.  This is called De Moivre's theorem.

\[ @q^n@ =@a^n@ e^{@b*n*%i*%pi@}.\]

Recall that

\[ e^{i\theta} = \cos(\theta)+i\sin(\theta).\]

Working with the principle argument $0\leq \theta \leq 2\pi$ gives us

\[ @q^n@ = @a^n@ e^{@b*n*%i*%pi@} = @a^n@ e^{@ev(b*n,simp)*%i*%pi@} = @a^n@ e^{@p*%i*%pi@}.\]
